More Notes: Industrial GDP is negatively affected by moderate and severe droughts, attributed to reduced hydroelectricity and upstream effects of poor agricultural production. Positive association with precipitation suggests benefits from hydroelectricity or agricultural inputs.
Agricultural GDP is negatively correlated with drought, positive rainfall anomalies measured over longer time periods are advantageous.
Drought coefficients are negative and statistically significant, both with and without temperature controls.
Regression performed using poverty headcounts as an alternate measure of economic progress.

Severe drought was strongly associated (99% CI) with increasing poverty counts. Dercon (2001) found rainfall shocks were the primary reason households fell into poverty. The value of '0' is only included as a placeholder, due to the lack of a specific numeric estimate in the provided text.
